discourse_list.title: Who all received this letter re:patents?

content.content: Governance Team, I never post here, because I’m on our firm’s investment team, but here goes - The letter attached claims a Maker patent infringement, but my lawyer says that a DAO’s 99.99% immune from any legal liability as long as its terms of use are complete. Maker looks good. Does anyone know Andreessen’s GC and can we get them to delete their paper that’s referenced in this letter? It’s not constructive and probably inaccurate. Given my lawyer’s analysis, I’d only [MAYBE] be concerned about a DAO tax liability or U.S. taxable connection. Thanks!  2021-12-09 TRS Ltr1275×1650 134 KB
Can you clarify what you mean by “terms of use are complete”? Thank you. Best regards, Kianga

if you conclude that all of Maker’s operations are solely based on code, and the terms of service disclaim “as is” or sophisticated user provisions, DAO’s like Maker should be essentially immune from any enforceable regulation or litigation

I don’t agree with that at all. People are behind the code and all the operations. Surely there is a banquet sized buffet of legal arguments, precedents and theories upon which persons (natural or entity) involved with DAOs can be drawn into enforcement actions and litigation regardless of disclaimers and terms of service. There are legal principles and powers that operate outside of the commercial code and contract law.

We believe that it’s more constructive if we all share the position that DAOs like Maker enjoy a supra-national and supra-state position vis-a-vis regulation and litigation, Otherwise, Andreessen’s (a16z) position comes into play, where a DAO could be liable for a regulatory violation or litigation relating to patents or other stuff. This line of analysis could ultimately result in a “look-through” to MKR holders which is an insane view. For example, I’m not liable for Apple patent violations simply because I own APPL shares. I do think it would be helpful for Andreessen-a16z to recant or correct this odd paper. Thanks

Here’s a helpful perspective from one of the members at Compound (comp.xyz) "I may not be a lawyer, but I do have a computer science degree and I often read academic papers. Patent No. US 10,025,797 B1 describes a system so general, vague, and incomplete that their “patented system” loosely describes smart contracts, off-chain oracle networks such as Chainlink, Merkel proofs, L2 scaling solutions, IPFS hashes, proof of history, and much more all at the same time, without going into any specifics. Definitely a patent troll."   Other points that have come up. They appear to be directing their arguments at Maker’s Oracle Security Modules from a couple of years ago. Are they are too late to make a two or three year old claim? Still the Achilles heel for patent owners is finding the one company that is infringing. Best case here it is a Maker’s codebase, which too bad for them, isn’t that one company you would need to attach to.

We are a service provider for many DAOs and Decentralized Exchanges. If you shop around, you can find legal counsel who are both constructive on the fully decentralised nature of DAOs and their stateless nature. Here’s a summary of their guidance. The best long run approach is not setting up a legal entity at all and to rely on a fully decentralized structure. DAOs without a registered legal entity can theoretically operate outside the law. In most jurisdictions, they may be seen as general partnerships, but without corresponding legal consequences. While there may be risk of the personal liability of every participant, because the DAO has no legal personality,  it can actually own assets and also employ people without risk of local law or regulation - consider it a shield. When participants do not legally register a DAO as an LLC or Company, they constructively avoid creating a fully recognized legal entity in most jurisdictions that can sue and can be sued. This is often misunderstood. Most DAO operators agree with these positions.

Well said. And we must further press for the correct policy approach and regulatory changes that provide protection and incentives for participants so as to unlock the superior outcomes (vis-à-vis the status quo) that await the world.

My firm may want a legal opinion which proves that MKR holders are shielded from any enforcement or lawsuit liabilities too. We can present this due diligence to our shareholders. Any names of law firms, preferably New York and California? Thank you for the perspective!

We generally operate out of the UK, Switzerland and sometimes Cayman SEZ, so our fact pattern may be different than others. I will see which memos I can share or post without jeopardising privilege. Generally, we recommend not holding DAO or DEX tokens in named wallets. It avoids many complications. We have heard clients working on DAO Onions or nested DAO arrangements. Onion DAOs give an operation a real supranational character and are consistent with jurisdicational optionality. Also, it’s best to keep any DAO or DEX tokens off centralized exchanges. As and when they begin tax reporting, that will introduces complications.

directly on point piece - DAOs are the foundation of Web3, the creator economy and the future of work “By replacing many intermediaries, the DAOs themselves acted as digital intermediaries that provide transparency and scale, giving them the stature of an organization without the traditional organizational constructs of entities, groups, management, charters and other forms of collective action. While the traditional centralized organizational structure is being challenged, the key organizational elements that remain are fueling a new economic revolution that is giving birth to a new creator economy and bringing artists, lawyers, developers and creators together from all around the globe to create ideas and monetize them at global scale in permissionless crypto economic systems built upon blockchain and Web3 technologies — and essentially defining the future of work.”
